column2: CHAPTER XIV.
column3: CHAPTER fourteen.

column2: BY and by, when we got up, we turned over the truck the gang had stole off of the wreck, and found boots, and blankets, and clothes, and all sorts of other things, and a lot of books, and a spyglass, and three boxes of seegars.
column3: BY and by, when we got up, we turned over the truck the gang had stole off of the wreck, and found boots, and blankets, and clothes, and all sorts of other things, and a lot of books, and a spyglass, and three boxes of seegars.

column2: We hadn't ever been this rich before in neither of our lives.
column3: We hadn't ever been this rich before in neither of our lives.

column2: The seegars was prime.
column3: The seegars was prime.

column2: We laid off all the afternoon in the woods talking, and me reading the books, and having a general good time.
column3: We laid off all the afternoon in the woods talking, and me reading the books, and having a general good time.

column2: I told Jim all about what happened inside the wreck and at the ferryboat, and I said these kinds of things was adventures; but he said he didn't want no more adventures.
column3: I told Jim all about what happened inside the wreck and at the ferryboat, and I said these kinds of things was adventures; but he said he didn't want no more adventures.

column2: He said that when I went in the texas and he crawled back to get on the raft and found her gone he nearly died, because he judged it was all up with _him_ anyway it could be fixed; for if he didn't get saved he would get drownded; and if he did get saved, whoever saved him would send him back home so as to get the reward, and then Miss Watson would sell him South, sure.
column3: He said that when I went in the texas and he crawled back to get on the raft and found her gone he nearly died, because he judged it was all up with underscore him underscore anyway it could be fixed; for if he didn't get saved he would get drownded; and if he did get saved, whoever saved him would send him back home so as to get the reward, and then Miss Watson would sell him South, sure.

column2: Well, he was right; he was most always right; he had an uncommon level head for a nigger.
column3: Well, he was right; he was most always right; he had an uncommon level head for a nigger.

column2: I read considerable to Jim about kings and dukes and earls and such, and how gaudy they dressed, and how much style they put on, and called each other your majesty, and your grace, and your lordship, and so on, 'stead of mister; and Jim's eyes bugged out, and he was interested.
column3: I read considerable to Jim about kings and dukes and earls and such, and how gaudy they dressed, and how much style they put on, and called each other your majesty, and your grace, and your lordship, and so on, 'stead of mister; and Jim's eyes bugged out, and he was interested.

column2: He says:
column3: He says:

column2: I didn' know dey was so many un um.	I d i d n' know dey was so many un um.
column3: false

column2: I hain't hearn 'bout none un um, skasely, but ole King Sollermun, onless you counts dem kings dat's in a pack er k'yards.
column3: I hain't hearn 'bout none un um, skasely, but ole King Sollermun, onless you counts dem kings dat's in a pack er k'yards.

column2: How much do a king git?"
column3: How much do a king git?"

column2: Get? I says; "why, they get a thousand dollars a month if they want it; they can have just as much as they want; everything belongs to them."
column3: Get? I says; "why, they get a thousand dollars a month if they want it; they can have just as much as they want; everything belongs to them."

column2: _Ain'_ dat gay?	underscore Ain' underscore dat gay?
column3: false

column2: En what dey got to do, Huck?"
column3: En what dey got to do, Huck?"

column2: _They_ don't do nothing!	underscore They underscore don't do nothing!
column3: false

column2: Why, how you talk!
column3: Why, how you talk!

column2: They just set around."
column3: They just set around."

column2: No; is dat so?
column3: No; is dat so?

column2: Of course it is.	Of course it is.
column3: false

column2: They just set aroundexcept, maybe, when there's a war; then they go to the war.
column3: They just set around  except, maybe, when there's a war; then they go to the war.

column2: But other times they just lazy around; or go hawkingjust hawking and spSh!d' you hear a noise?"
column3: But other times they just lazy around; or go hawking  just hawking and s p  Sh!  d' you hear a noise?"

column2: We skipped out and looked; but it warn't nothing but the flutter of a steamboat's wheel away down, coming around the point; so we come back.
column3: We skipped out and looked; but it warn't nothing but the flutter of a steamboat's wheel away down, coming around the point; so we come back.

column2: Yes, says I, "and other times, when things is dull, they fuss with the parlyment; and if everybody don't go just so he whacks their heads off. But mostly they hang round the harem."
column3: Yes, says I, "and other times, when things is dull, they fuss with the parlyment; and if everybody don't go just so he whacks their heads off. But mostly they hang round the harem."

column2: Roun' de which?
column3: Roun' de which?

column2: Harem.
column3: Harem.

column2: What's de harem?
column3: What's de harem?

column2: The place where he keeps his wives.	The place where he keeps his wives.
column3: false

column2: Don't you know about the harem? Solomon had one; he had about a million wives."
column3: Don't you know about the harem? Solomon had one; he had about a million wives."

column2: Why, yes, dat's so; II'd done forgot it.	Why, yes, dat's so; I  I'd done forgot it.
column3: false

column2: A harem's a bo'd'n-house, I reck'n.
column3: A harem's a bo'd'n house, I reck'n.

column2: Mos' likely dey has rackety times in de nussery.
column3: Mos' likely dey has rackety times in de nussery.

column2: En I reck'n de wives quarrels considable; en dat 'crease de racket.
column3: En I reck'n de wives quarrels considable; en dat 'crease de racket.

column2: Yit dey say Sollermun de wises' man dat ever live'.
column3: y i t dey say Sollermun de wises' man dat ever live'.

column2: I doan' take no stock in dat.
column3: I doan' take no stock in dat.

column2: Bekase why: would a wise man want to live in de mids' er sich a blim-blammin' all de time?
column3: Bekase why: would a wise man want to live in de mids' er sich a blim blammin' all de time?

column2: No'deed he wouldn't.
column3: No  'deed he wouldn't.

column2: A wise man 'ud take en buil' a biler-factry; en den he could shet _down_ de biler-factry when he want to res'."
column3: A wise man 'u d take en buil' a biler factry; en den he could shet underscore down underscore de biler factry when he want to res'."

column2: Well, but he _was_ the wisest man, anyway; because the widow she told me so, her own self.
column3: Well, but he underscore was underscore the wisest man, anyway; because the widow she told me so, her own self.

column2: I doan k'yer what de widder say, he _warn't_ no wise man nuther.	I doan k'yer what de widder say, he underscore warn't underscore no wise man nuther.
column3: false

column2: He had some er de dad-fetchedes' ways I ever see.
column3: He had some er de dad fetchedes' ways I ever see.

column2: Does you know 'bout dat chile dat he 'uz gwyne to chop in two?"
column3: Does you know 'bout dat chile dat he 'u z gwyne to chop in two?"

column2: Yes, the widow told me all about it.
column3: Yes, the widow told me all about it.

column2: _Well_, den!	underscore Well underscore, den!
column3: false

column2: Warn' dat de beatenes' notion in de worl'?
column3: Warn' dat de beatenes' notion in de worl'?

column2: You jes' take en look at it a minute.
column3: You jes' take en look at it a minute.

column2: Dah's de stump, dahdat's one er de women; heah's youdat's de yuther one; I's Sollermun; en dish yer dollar bill's de chile.
column3: Dah's de stump, dah  dat's one er de women; heah's you  dat's de yuther one; I's Sollermun; en dish yer dollar bill's de chile.

column2: Bofe un you claims it.
column3: Bofe un you claims it.

column2: What does I do?
column3: What does I do?

column2: Does I shin aroun' mongs' de neighbors en fine out which un you de bill _do_ b'long to, en han' it over to de right one, all safe en soun', de way dat anybody dat had any gumption would?
column3: Does I shin aroun' mongs' de neighbors en fine out which un you de bill underscore do underscore b'long to, en han' it over to de right one, all safe en soun', de way dat anybody dat had any gumption would?

column2: No; I take en whack de bill in _two_, en give half un it to you, en de yuther half to de yuther woman.
column3: No; I take en whack de bill in underscore two underscore, en give half un it to you, en de yuther half to de yuther woman.

column2: Dat's de way Sollermun was gwyne to do wid de chile.
column3: Dat's de way Sollermun was gwyne to do wid de chile.

column2: Now I want to ast you: what's de use er dat half a bill?can't buy noth'n wid it.
column3: Now I want to ast you: what's de use er dat half a bill?  can't buy noth'n wid it.

column2: En what use is a half a chile?
column3: En what use is a half a chile?

column2: I wouldn' give a dern for a million un um."
column3: I wouldn' give a dern for a million un um."

column2: But hang it, Jim, you've clean missed the pointblame it, you've missed it a thousand mile.
column3: But hang it, Jim, you've clean missed the point  blame it, you've missed it a thousand mile.

column2: Who?	Who?
column3: true

column2: Me? Go 'long.
column3: Me? Go 'long.

column2: Doan' talk to me 'bout yo' pints.
column3: Doan' talk to me 'bout yo' pints.

column2: I reck'n I knows sense when I sees it; en dey ain' no sense in sich doin's as dat.
column3: I reck'n I knows sense when I sees it; en dey ain' no sense in sich doin's as dat.

column2: De 'spute warn't 'bout a half a chile, de 'spute was 'bout a whole chile; en de man dat think he kin settle a 'spute 'bout a whole chile wid a half a chile doan' know enough to come in out'n de rain.
column3: De 'spute warn't 'bout a half a chile, de 'spute was 'bout a whole chile; en de man dat think he kin settle a 'spute 'bout a whole chile wid a half a chile doan' know enough to come in out'n de rain.

column2: Doan' talk to me 'bout Sollermun, Huck, I knows him by de back."
column3: Doan' talk to me 'bout Sollermun, Huck, I knows him by de back."

column2: But I tell you you don't get the point.
column3: But I tell you you don't get the point.

column2: Blame de point!	Blame de point!
column3: false

column2: I reck'n I knows what I knows.
column3: I reck'n I knows what I knows.

column2: En mine you, de _real_ pint is down furderit's down deeper.
column3: En mine you, de underscore real underscore pint is down furder  it's down deeper.

column2: It lays in de way Sollermun was raised.
column3: It lays in de way Sollermun was raised.

column2: You take a man dat's got on'y one or two chillen; is dat man gwyne to be waseful o' chillen?
column3: You take a man dat's got on'y one or two chillen; is dat man gwyne to be waseful o' chillen?

column2: No, he ain't; he can't 'ford it.
column3: No, he ain't; he can't 'ford it.

column2: _He_ know how to value 'em.
column3: underscore He underscore know how to value 'em.

column2: But you take a man dat's got 'bout five million chillen runnin' roun' de house, en it's diffunt.
column3: But you take a man dat's got 'bout five million chillen runnin' roun' de house, en it's diffunt.

column2: _He_ as soon chop a chile in two as a cat.
column3: underscore He underscore as soon chop a chile in two as a cat.

column2: Dey's plenty mo'.
column3: Dey's plenty mo'.

column2: A chile er two, mo' er less, warn't no consekens to Sollermun, dad fatch him!"
column3: A chile er two, mo' er less, warn't no consekens to Sollermun, dad fatch him!"

column2: I never see such a nigger.
column3: I never see such a nigger.

column2: If he got a notion in his head once, there warn't no getting it out again.
column3: If he got a notion in his head once, there warn't no getting it out again.

column2: He was the most down on Solomon of any nigger I ever see.
column3: He was the most down on Solomon of any nigger I ever see.

column2: So I went to talking about other kings, and let Solomon slide.
column3: So I went to talking about other kings, and let Solomon slide.

column2: I told about Louis Sixteenth that got his head cut off in France long time ago; and about his little boy the dolphin, that would a been a king, but they took and shut him up in jail, and some say he died there.
column3: I told about Louis Sixteenth that got his head cut off in France long time ago; and about his little boy the dolphin, that would a been a king, but they took and shut him up in jail, and some say he died there.

column2: Po' little chap.
column3: Po' little chap.

column2: But some says he got out and got away, and come to America.
column3: But some says he got out and got away, and come to America.

column2: Dat's good!	Dat's good!
column3: true

column2: But he'll be pooty lonesomedey ain' no kings here, is dey, Huck?"
column3: But he'll be pooty lonesome  dey ain' no kings here, is dey, Huck?"

column2: No.
column3: no

column2: Den he cain't git no situation.	Den he cain't git no situation.
column3: false

column2: What he gwyne to do?"
column3: What he gwyne to do?"

column2: Well, I don't know.	Well, I don't know.
column3: true

column2: Some of them gets on the police, and some of them learns people how to talk French."
column3: Some of them gets on the police, and some of them learns people how to talk French."

column2: Why, Huck, doan' de French people talk de same way we does?
column3: Why, Huck, doan' de French people talk de same way we does?

column2: _No_, Jim; you couldn't understand a word they saidnot a single word.
column3: underscore No underscore, Jim; you couldn't understand a word they said  not a single word.

column2: Well, now, I be ding-busted!	Well, now, I be ding busted!
column3: true

column2: How do dat come?"
column3: How do dat come?"

column2: I don't know; but it's so.	I don't know; but it's so.
column3: true

column2: I got some of their jabber out of a book. S'pose a man was to come to you and say Polly-voo-franzywhat would you think?"
column3: I got some of their jabber out of a book. S'pose a man was to come to you and say Polly voo franzy  what would you think?"

column2: I wouldn' think nuff'n; I'd take en bust him over de headdat is, if he warn't white.	I wouldn' think nuff'n; I'd take en bust him over de head  dat is, if he warn't white.
column3: false

column2: I wouldn't 'low no nigger to call me dat."
column3: I wouldn't 'low no nigger to call me dat."

column2: Shucks, it ain't calling you anything.	Shucks, it ain't calling you anything.
column3: true

column2: It's only saying, do you know how to talk French?"
column3: It's only saying, do you know how to talk French?"

column2: Well, den, why couldn't he _say_ it?
column3: Well, den, why couldn't he underscore say underscore it?

column2: Why, he _is_ a-saying it.	Why, he underscore is underscore a saying it.
column3: false

column2: That's a Frenchman's _way_ of saying it."
column3: That's a Frenchman's underscore way underscore of saying it."

column2: Well, it's a blame ridicklous way, en I doan' want to hear no mo' 'bout it.	Well, it's a blame ridicklous way, en I doan' want to hear no mo' 'bout it.
column3: false

column2: Dey ain' no sense in it."
column3: Dey ain' no sense in it."

column2: Looky here, Jim; does a cat talk like we do?
column3: Looky here, Jim; does a cat talk like we do?

column2: No, a cat don't.
column3: No, a cat don't.

column2: Well, does a cow?
column3: Well, does a cow?

column2: No, a cow don't, nuther.
column3: No, a cow don't, nuther.

column2: Does a cat talk like a cow, or a cow talk like a cat?
column3: Does a cat talk like a cow, or a cow talk like a cat?

column2: No, dey don't.
column3: No, dey don't.

column2: It's natural and right for 'em to talk different from each other, ain't it?
column3: It's natural and right for 'em to talk different from each other, ain't it?

column2: Course.
column3: Course.

column2: And ain't it natural and right for a cat and a cow to talk different from _us_?
column3: And ain't it natural and right for a cat and a cow to talk different from underscore us underscore?

column2: Why, mos' sholy it is.
column3: Why, mos' sholy it is.

column2: Well, then, why ain't it natural and right for a _Frenchman_ to talk different from us?	Well, then, why ain't it natural and right for a underscore Frenchman underscore to talk different from us?
column3: false

column2: You answer me that."
column3: You answer me that."

column2: Is a cat a man, Huck?
column3: Is a cat a man, Huck?

column2: No.
column3: no

column2: Well, den, dey ain't no sense in a cat talkin' like a man.	Well, den, dey ain't no sense in a cat talkin' like a man.

column2: Is a cow a man?er is a cow a cat?"
column3: Is a cow a man?  er is a cow a cat?"

column2: No, she ain't either of them.
column3: No, she ain't either of them.

column2: Well, den, she ain't got no business to talk like either one er the yuther of 'em.	Well, den, she ain't got no business to talk like either one er the yuther of 'em.

column2: Is a Frenchman a man?"
column3: Is a Frenchman a man?"
